items.title: 3.4.1 Tooltip sanitization breaks popover with tables
items.body:
Is there any reason why `` is not whitelisted by the sanitizeHtml function? https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap-sass/blob/b34765d8a6aa775816c59012b2d6b30c4c66a8e9/assets/javascripts/bootstrap.js#L1313 This is was breaking change for us realeased as a **patch**. Looking at the source code I found that I could set `saniteze: false`, but I don't see why it would be required to turn sanitization off completely just to be able to use tables. Are there any known vulnerabilities regarding tables that I'm not aware of? ```js $('#button').popover({ html: true, content: function () { return `
Table below
Foo:bar
`; } }) ``` Minimal reproduction: https://jsfiddle.net/Victornpb/u1q7cjft/

items.title: v3.4.1 data attributes are removed from links
items.body: Hello, I'm using `bootstrap-sass` in a rails project and I write in a view something like: ```ruby <%= link_to "link name", foo_path class: 'btn btn-primary', remote: true, data: {bar: true} %> ``` Since the update of the gem to version `3.4.1`, the commit 69157ce76df1ccff394803811e582979cda4a993 seems to sanitize the links and remove the `date-remote` and `data-bar` attributes from the `a` tag, something like that will be render: ```html link_name ``` I wonder if it a bug from `bootstrap-sass` (should `data-*` attributes be really removed in the sanitation process?) or if I need to handle it in my app (use `remote: true` is really standard rails)?

Here are the relevant portions of the build output (the line "Processing..." comes from a modification I made to the sprockets code - without it, I couldn't isolate which file was breaking):

Everything was working when we were using bower, and we've made minimal changes to other files during the transition process.

items.title: HTML popovers broken in 3.4.1
items.body:
It looks like the `sanitize` option was added in 3.4.1 (commit 69157ce76df1ccff394803811e582979cda4a993) and defaults to true.  This breaks most existing HTML popovers. Setting it to false gets the old behavior (obviously it's up to dev to ensure the HTML they use is safe).

Was this an accident or intentional?  It wasn't listed in changes and it's a breaking change that ignores semver norms.

It's also odd that 3.4.1 doesn't even have a section in CHANGELOG.md, was it even supposed to be released?

Github's dependency checker flagged CVE's based on the version of ejs in package.json (2.4.2):

Sass precision (default = 5) too low for $line-height-base calculation
items.body:
in _variables.scss $line-height-base is set to 1.428571429
Sass cuts this to 1.42857. This leads to different heights in button and text Inputs. Text inputs are 1px higher. (osx, chrome)
In my gruntfile I had to set "precision: 8". Now it calculates to 1.42857143 which makes the buttons and input fields the same height.

Maybe there should be a note about the precision setting in sass to handle this issue.

![bootstrap_sass_precision](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7041767/31766294-72465e7e-b4c7-11e7-8f87-c9eb665ed015.png)

items.title: inverted ceil() and floor() in make-row mixin
items.body:
I just came across a minor issue while debugging another.

I think ceil() and floor() are inverted in the make-row mixin here.
https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap-sass/blob/master/assets/stylesheets/bootstrap/mixins/_grid.scss#L16

The rounded number will always be negative so the result will actually work the opposite way as it does in the col mixins here:
https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap-sass/blob/master/assets/stylesheets/bootstrap/mixins/_grid-framework.scss#L16

In a nutshell the bug shifts the visible content 1px to the right if the grid-gutter-width is an odd number.

little example (first row broken, second default, third fixed):
https://codepen.io/quarkus/pen/oGydpW?editors=1100

Pretty hard to see as its just one pixel, but its noticable on the left edge of the cols

items.title: clean up font face rules?
items.body:
https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap-sass/blob/master/assets/stylesheets/bootstrap/_glyphicons.scss looks to still contains several now-questionable formats:

- there are no longer any browsers that support `eot`, as the only browsers that supported `eot` were Microsoft IE4 through IE8, all of which have been finally killed off in January of 2016, with Microsoft only officially supporting IE11 and Edge, and for very special enterprise customers, IE9 on Vista SP2. All of these browsers support `woff`, thus making `eot` obsolete and redundant.
- the `svg` font format was abandoned when it become more than apparent it that it was wildly unsuitable for encoding fonts, to the point where the official SVG specifically *removed* the chapter on font-related markup, marking it as out-of-spec markup. SVG-compliant browsers have since removed support for it (because it's no longer part of the spec) and the only browser that still officially supports `svg` fonts also supports `woff`, making `svg` also both obsolete and redundant.
- the `ttf` and `otf` formats, as full-table, uncompressed system fonts, are also not necessary: browsers that support these formats also support `woff`, and should always prefer to load the `woff` resource if one is available. The only exception could be said to be Android 2.x through 4.2.x, but these versions have terrible web font support even when using `ttf` and are on the same level of "you're on your own" when it comes to webfonts as we used to be when we tried to make modern CSS work on IE6, 7, and 8. `ttf` and `otf` also don't enjoy the benefit of compression that `woff` comes with.

So for modern bootstrap, really the only formats needed are `woff` and `woff2`, with the latter of course being preferred because it has better compression for faster delivery over the wire.

items.title: Dependencies error with new Laravel webpack (npm run dev)
items.body:
**Information**

With the release of the new laravel (5.4) and the default usage of the new webpack instead of gulp to compile all resources using `npm run dev` also came a new way to load url's in sass. Instead of paths like; `../fonts/bootstrap/font.eot` there now a need to have the paths look like this: `~/fonts/bootstrap/font.eot`.

I'm not really sure how non-laravel projects react to this change though since I can't test that unfortunately, thus why I post this as an issue instead of a pull request.

I hope someone else could possibly test this change in a non-laravel environment so I (or someone else) can post the updated path as a pull request.

**The changes that need to be made are as follows:**

1. Go to `node_modules/bootstrap-sass/assets/stylesheets/bootstrap/_variables.scss` on **line 83**.
2. Change `"../fonts/bootstrap/"` to `"~/../fonts/bootstrap/"`.

**How to duplicate this error**

1. Setup a (fresh) laravel 5.4 environment using the new webpack and npm.
2. Add bootstrap-sass and run the `npm install` command.
3. After the install is done, run `npm run dev`.

**Exact error relevant for the bootstrap-sass module:**
```
These dependencies were not found in node_modules:

* ../fonts/bootstrap/glyphicons-halflings-regular.eot
* ../fonts/bootstrap/glyphicons-halflings-regular.woff2
* ../fonts/bootstrap/glyphicons-halflings-regular.woff
* ../fonts/bootstrap/glyphicons-halflings-regular.ttf
* ../fonts/bootstrap/glyphicons-halflings-regular.svg
```

items.title: Breadcrumb variable interpolation breaking sourcemaps
items.body:
For reference - https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap-sass/issues/919

I think the above issue has to be reopened. Sorry if I should be posting there, kinda new to github and its issue/bug tracking.

So from what I can tell, there used to be an issue with how libsass compiled the following:

```
content: "#{$breadcrumb-separator}\00a0";
```

So it got changed to:

```
$nbsp: "\00a0";
content: "#{$breadcrumb-separator}#{$nbsp}";
```

But now that leads to it getting compiled to:

```
content: "/ ";
```

And on top of that if the libsass output style is set to `compressed` it causes source maps to be inaccurate. The other output styles are fine though. I submitted an issue over there - https://github.com/sass/libsass/issues/2319

# Proposition

Because this whole variable interpolation stuff is pretty unreliable and inconsistent across recent versions of libsass, I propose to just hardcode the value. So...

```
content: "/\00a0";
```

That way it will work for people using slightly older versions of libsass and also for people using the recent version(s). And though we won't have a simple variable to change/override, it's super easy to override the old fashion way. For example

```
.breadcrumb>li+li:before {
    content: "\003e\00a0"; // for a ">" instead of a "/"
}
```

I'd much rather have minified css and source maps than a variable for breadcrumbs. I know, as a work around, I could use a separate css minifier, but they add nearly one second to compile time. Libsass is fast and hard to beat and I really like to keep things simple and fast whenever possible.

Thoughts on this?

items.title: Unnecesary files included in npm package
items.body:
I noticed that the npm package includes some files that cannot be helpful to consumers. The test directory is included with some transient files - the rails tmp dir and log dir for example. 

Test against the package version we are using:
`curl -s  https://registry.npmjs.org/bootstrap-sass/-/bootstrap-sass-3.3.6.tgz | tar ztv | grep -c dummy_rails/tmp`

> 291

Example: 
`curl -s  https://registry.npmjs.org/bootstrap-sass/-/bootstrap-sass-3.3.6.tgz | tar ztv | grep dummy_rails/tmp`

> `-rw-rw-r-- 1000/1000       198 2015-09-27 07:50 package/test/dummy_rails/tmp/cache/sprockets/v4.0/Vygbc35Z0fLTFlt6RrFwpQyO45HqPALfeo4lCR1vX7o.cache
> ...`

I realize this is not adversely affecting anyone but I think if the solution is clean then the reduced size will be worth it (uncompressed the tmp/cache dir was 1.7M). I don't have experience setting up npm builds but if someone can point me in the right direction I'm happy to get a PR going to tackle this low-hanging fruit.

items.title: eyeglass import is not consistent with rails/bower/node/etc
items.body:
In [#1007](https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap-sass/pull/1007), Eyeglass support was added. This was a great improvement for us as it allowed us to pull more dependencies in through npm.

We have a sass library that works both in Rails's asset pipeline and in other ecosystems. The eyeglass import having a different name in Eyeglass unfortunately makes us choose between only supporting building through eyeglass, or not having eyeglass support and having everything else work.

For example, in Rails:

``` scss
@import "bootstrap";
```

But in eyeglass:

``` scss
@import "bootstrap-sass/bootstrap";
```

If you look at the README in its current state you can see how consistent it is until you get down to the Eyeglass section.

This could be fixed by adding a `name` field to the `eyeglass` section package.json for `bootstrap-sass`:

``` json
{
  "name": "bootstrap-sass",
  "version": "1.1.0",
  "eyeglass": {
    "name": "bootstrap",
    "needs": "^0.6.7",
    "exports": "eyeglass-exports.js"
  }
```

For consistency, I think it would be great if you could `@import "bootstrap"` in any ecosystem and have it work.

This would be a breaking change for anybody currently using eyeglass, but an easy fix to implement (change your import statements to "@import bootstrap").

items.title: Don't use @extend with classnames
Sass @import "bootstrap-compass" + @import "bootstrap" issue using Compass.
items.body:
I've created a new project using `compass create <my-project-name> -r bootstrap-sass --using bootstrap` and when I open styles.scss I see the following code: 

```
// Import Bootstrap Compass integration
@import "bootstrap-compass";

// Import custom Bootstrap variables
@import "bootstrap-variables";

// Import Bootstrap for Sass
@import "bootstrap";
```

Now I am using PHPStorm and `@import "bootstrap-compass";` and `@import "bootstrap";` are showing up as red lines. Upon hover it says **Cannot resolve file 'bootstrap'** and **Cannot resolve file 'bootstrap-compass'**.

I've tried to run the following command (again):

```
$ gem install bootstrap-sass
Successfully installed bootstrap-sass-3.3.7
Parsing documentation for bootstrap-sass-3.3.7
Done installing documentation for bootstrap-sass after 0 seconds
1 gem installed
$ 
```

But it doesn't fix the error. 

My project tree looks like this after a fresh `compass create my-new-project -r bootstrap-sass --using bootstrap`:

```
.
├── config.rb
├── fonts
│   └── bootstrap
│       ├── glyphicons-halflings-regular.eot
│       ├── glyphicons-halflings-regular.svg
│       ├── glyphicons-halflings-regular.ttf
│       ├── glyphicons-halflings-regular.woff
│       └── glyphicons-halflings-regular.woff2
├── javascripts
│   ├── bootstrap
│   │   ├── affix.js
│   │   ├── alert.js
│   │   ├── button.js
│   │   ├── carousel.js
│   │   ├── collapse.js

items.title: z-index for .modal
items.body: In bootstrap cdns I see that .modal has a z-index of 1050.  This is not the case in this repository. Line 25 of _modal.scss is   z-index: $zindex-modal-background;  and that value is 1040. This causes the problem where the modal is inactive because it is under the backdrop.  That line must be substituted with   z-index: $zindex-modal;

items.body:
bootstrap modals don't work with jQuery 3.0:  https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap/issues/16834

I found this to be the case.

I am installing bootstrap with bower and it depends on jQuery.  bootstrap-sass goes and gets version 3.0 of jQuery and then the modal won't work.

This is direct from bootstrap-sass:  https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap-sass/blob/3.3-stable/bower.json 

  "dependencies": {
    "jquery": ">= 1.9.0"
  },  
  "version": "3.3.6"

So, I think it would help if the version on the dependency was changed.

In the meantime, I did this:

`bower uninstall jquery`

`bower install jquery#2.2.4`

I had to confirm the uninstall.  I don't know what the best version of jQuery to use is.  2.2.4 let my modal work.

items.title: Expose scss file in "style" field of package.json
items.body:
Hello,

I am trying use `bootstrap-sass` via `npm`, `node-sass` and the `sass-module-importer`. The importer [documents](https://www.npmjs.com/package/sass-module-importer) this lookup strategy:

```
1. Set a SCSS/Sass/CSS file on the "main" field of their package.json/bower.json
2. Set a SCSS/Sass/CSS file on the "style" field of their package.json/bower.json
3. Have a index.css file on the root of their module
```

If I look at the `bootstrap` npm package, [it uses](https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap/blob/7c86bc9664ddc3a1965fe91d7a0db97eb9348448/package.json#L21) the `style` field in `package.json`. It seems [this field is becoming a de facto standard](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/32037150/style-field-in-package-json).

Is it possible to get a similar setup and expose the main scss file in the `style` field of `package.json`?

items.title: Update jQuery dependency resolution
items.body:
When pulling in bootstrap-sass via bower, the jQuery dependency rule is set to `"jquery": ">= 1.9.0"` but bootstrap will throw an Error if jQuery 3.x is used. Since jQuery just released 3.0, this is breaking builds in the wild.

Suggest updating your dependency rule to match bootstrap: `"jquery": "1.9.1 - 2"`

items.title: bower.json should restrict to jquery < 3?
items.body:
This issue is to suggest restricting jquery to < 3 in bower.json.  Currently (as of 3.3.6), Bootstrap's bower.json says this (from [here](https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap/blob/v3.3.6/bower.json#L32)):

```
"jquery": "1.9.1 - 2"
```

But this project's bower.json says this:

```
"jquery": ">= 1.9.0"
```

The user will get an error like the following at runtime if jquery 3 winds up getting installed: "Bootstrap's JavaScript requires jQuery version 1.9.1 or higher, but lower than version 3"
